key_points: A cybersecurity attack on the Colonial Pipeline has caused fuel shortages and panic-buying in parts of the Southeastern U.S.
North Carolina and Virginia declared states of emergency to help ensure gas supply and access.
Colonial Pipeline initiated restart operations but stated deliveries to normal would take several days.
Seventy-one percent of gas stations in North Carolina reported having no gas.
Incidents of violence occurred at gas stations due to tensions over gas availability.
The cybersecurity attack raised concerns about the vulnerability of the nation's critical infrastructure.
Governor Roy Cooper of North Carolina urged residents not to panic buy and report gas price gouging.
The attack highlighted a transportation issue rather than a lack of fuel supply, with ample fuel available for the summer.
Colonial Pipeline delivers about 45% of the fuel consumed on the East Coast.
The cyberattack led to worries among workers dependent on fuel, like tow-truck driver Jonathan King.
